questiontext.text:
Evaluate \(\displaystyle\int_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr}\), where \(\underline{F} = (x-y)\underline{i} + (x+y)\underline{j}\) along each of the following paths

  1. \(C_1\) : from \(({@aa@},{@aa^2@})\) to \(({@bb@},{@bb^2@})\) along the straight line \(y = {@gradient*x+intercept@}\):

    \(\displaystyle\int_{C_1} \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr}=\)[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

  2. \(C_2\) : from \(({@aa@},{@aa^2@})\) to \(({@bb@},{@bb^2@})\) along the parabola \(y = x^2\):

    \(\displaystyle\int_{C_2} \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr}=\)[[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]][[feedback:prt2]]

  3. \(C_3\) : along the straight line \(x={@aa@}\) from \(({@aa@},{@aa^2@})\) to \(({@aa@},{@bb^2@})\) then along the straight line \(y={@bb^2@}\) from \(({@aa@},{@bb^2@})\) to \(({@bb@},{@bb^2@})\).

    \(\displaystyle\int_{C_3} \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr}=\)[[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]][[feedback:prt3]]

For the function \(\underline{F}\) and the above paths, deduce \(\displaystyle\oint \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr}\) for the closed paths

  1. For: \(C_1\) followed by the reverse of \(C_2\), \(\displaystyle\oint \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr} =\)[[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]][[feedback:prt4]]
  2. For: \(C_2\) followed by the reverse of \(C_3\)), \(\displaystyle\oint \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr} =\)[[input:ans5]] [[validation:ans5]][[feedback:prt5]]
  3. For: \(C_3\) followed by the reverse of \(C_1\)), \(\displaystyle\oint \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr} =\)[[input:ans6]] [[validation:ans6]][[feedback:prt6]]

generalfeedback.text:
We know that \(\underline{F} = (x-y)\underline{i} + (x+y)\underline{j}\), and aim to evaluate \(\displaystyle\int_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr}\) along the following three paths:

(a) \(C_1\) : from \(({@aa@},{@aa^2@})\) to \(({@bb@},{@bb^2@})\) along the straight line \(y = {@gradient*x+intercept@}\).

We aim to write the line integral in terms of \(x\). Parametrising \(\underline{r}\) in terms of \(x\) and then aiming to find \(\underline{F}\cdot\dfrac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}x}\), we find: \[\begin{aligned} \underline{r} &= x\underline{i}+ ({@yy@})\underline{j}\\ \frac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}x} &= \underline{i}+ {@gradient@}\underline{j}\\ \underline{F} &= ({@x-yy@})\underline{i}+ ({@x+yy@})\underline{j}\\ \underline{F}\cdot\dfrac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}x} &= {@ev(x-yy + gradient*(x+yy),simp)@} \\ &={@(gradient^2+1)*x+ intercept*(gradient-1)@}. \end{aligned}\]

Therefore, we may solve the line integral as follows: \[\begin{aligned} \int_{C_1} \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr} &= \int^{@bb@}_{@aa@} \underline{F}\cdot\dfrac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}x}\ \mathrm{d}x \\ &= \int^{@bb@}_{@aa@} {@(gradient^2+1)*x+ intercept*(gradient-1)@}\ \mathrm{d}x \\ &= \left[{@(gradient^2+1)/2@}x^2 +{@intercept*(gradient-1)@}x\right]^{@bb@}_{@aa@}\\ &= \left({@(gradient^2+1)/2@}({@bb@})^2 +{@intercept*(gradient-1)@}({@bb@})\right) - \left({@(gradient^2+1)/2@}({@aa@})^2 +{@intercept*(gradient-1)@}({@aa@})\right) \\ &= \left({@((gradient^2+1)/2)*(bb^2) +intercept*(gradient-1)*bb@}\right) - \left({@((gradient^2+1)/2)*(aa^2) +intercept*(gradient-1)*aa@}\right) \\ &={@((gradient^2+1)/2)*(bb^2) +intercept*(gradient-1)*bb - (((gradient^2+1)/2)*(aa^2) +intercept*(gradient-1)*aa)@} \end{aligned}\]

(b) \(C_2\) : from \(({@aa@},{@aa^2@})\) to \(({@bb@},{@bb^2@})\) along the parabola \(y = x^2\).

We again aim to write the line integral in terms of \(x\). Parametrising \(\underline{r}\) in terms of \(x\) and then aiming to find \(\underline{F}\cdot\dfrac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}x}\), we find: \[\begin{aligned} \underline{r} &= x\underline{i}+ x^2\underline{j}\\ \frac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}x} &= \underline{i}+ 2x\underline{j}\\ \underline{F} &= (x-x^2)\underline{i}+ (x+x^2)\underline{j}\\ \underline{F}\cdot\dfrac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}x} &= (x-x^2) + 2x(x+x^2)\\ &=x + x^2 + 2x^3 \end{aligned}\].

Therefore, we may solve the line integral as follows: \[\begin{aligned} \int_{C_2} \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr} &= \int^{@bb@}_{@aa@} \underline{F}\cdot\dfrac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}x}\ \mathrm{d}x \\ &= \int^{@bb@}_{@aa@} x + x^2 + 2x^3\ \mathrm{d}x \\ &= \left[\frac{x^2}{2} + \frac{x^3}{3} + \frac{x^4}{2}\right]^{@bb@}_{@aa@}\\ &= \left(\frac{({@bb@})^2}{2} + \frac{({@bb@})^3}{3} + \frac{({@bb@})^4}{2}\right) - \left(\frac{({@aa@})^2}{2} + \frac{({@aa@})^3}{3} + \frac{({@aa@})^4}{2}\right) \\ &= \left({@(bb^2)/2 + (bb^3)/3 + (bb^4)/2@}\right) - \left({@(aa^2)/2 + (aa^3)/3 + (aa^4)/2@}\right) \\ &={@(bb^2)/2 + (bb^3)/3 + (bb^4)/2 - ((aa^2)/2 + (aa^3)/3 + (aa^4)/2)@} \end{aligned}\]

(c) \(C_3\) : along the straight line \(x={@aa@}\) from \(({@aa@},{@aa^2@})\) to \(({@aa@},{@bb^2@})\) then along the straight line \(y={@bb^2@}\) from \(({@aa@},{@bb^2@})\) to \(({@bb@},{@bb^2@})\).

We again aim to write the line integral as the sum of two separate line integrals, one in terms of \(x\) and the other in terms of \(y\). Parametrising \(\underline{r_1}\) in terms of \(y\) and then aiming to find \(\underline{F}\cdot\dfrac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r_1}}{\mathrm{d}x}\), we find: \[\begin{aligned} \underline{r} &= {@aa@}\underline{i}+ y\underline{j}\\ \frac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r_1}}{\mathrm{d}y} &= \underline{j}\\ \underline{F} &= ({@aa@}-y)\underline{i}+ ({@aa@}+y)\underline{j}\\ \underline{F}\cdot\dfrac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r_1}}{\mathrm{d}y} &= {@aa@}+y\\ \end{aligned}\]

Now parametrising \(\underline{r_2}\) in terms of \(x\) and then aiming to find \(\underline{F}\cdot\dfrac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r_2}}{\mathrm{d}x}\), we find: \[\begin{aligned} \underline{r} &= x\underline{i}+ {@bb^2@}\underline{j}\\ \frac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r_2}}{\mathrm{d}x} &= \underline{i}\\ \underline{F} &= (x-{@bb^2@})\underline{i}+ (x+{@bb^2@})\underline{j}\\ \underline{F}\cdot\dfrac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r_2}}{\mathrm{d}x} &= x-{@bb^2@}\\ \end{aligned}\]

Therefore, we may solve the line integral as follows: \[\begin{aligned} \int_{C_3} \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr} &= \int^{@bb^2@}_{@aa^2@} \underline{F} \cdot \dfrac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r_1}}{\mathrm{d}y}\ \mathrm{d}y + \int^{@bb@}_{@aa@} \underline{F} \cdot \dfrac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r_2}}{\mathrm{d}x}\ \mathrm{d}x\\ &= \int^{@bb^2@}_{@aa^2@} {@aa@}+y\ \mathrm{d}y + \int^{@bb@}_{@aa@} x-{@bb^2@}\ \mathrm{d}x \\ &= \left[{@aa@}y+\frac{y^2}{2}\right]^{@bb^2@}_{@aa^2@} + \left[\frac{x^2}{2}-{@bb^2@}x\right]^{@bb@}_{@aa@}\\ &= \left[ \left({@aa@}({@bb^2@})+\frac{({@bb^2@})^2}{2}\right) - \left({@aa@}({@aa^2@})+\frac{({@aa^2@})^2}{2}\right) \right] +\left[\left(\frac{({@bb@})^2}{2}-{@bb^2@}({@bb@})\right) -\left(\frac{({@aa@})^2}{2}-{@bb^2@}({@aa@})\right)\right]\\ &=\left[ {@aa*(bb^2)+(bb^4)/2 - (aa*(aa^2)+(aa^4)/2)@} \right] + \left[{@(bb^2)/2-bb^3 -((aa^2)/2-bb^2*aa)@}\right] \\ &= {@aa*(bb^2)+(bb^4)/2 - (aa*(aa^2)+(aa^4)/2) + (bb^2)/2-bb^3 -((aa^2)/2-bb^2*aa)@} \end{aligned}\]

Using our answers from the previous part, we find:

(d) \(\displaystyle\oint \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr} ={@ta1@}-{@ta2@} = {@ta4@}\)

(e) \(\displaystyle\oint \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr} ={@ta2@}-{@ta3@} = {@ta5@}\)

(f) \(\displaystyle\oint \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr} ={@ta3@}-{@ta1@} = {@ta6@}\)

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

qtest.description: Test case assuming the teacher's input gets full marks.
